overall_score_comment: It's like if Shakespeare had a fever dream during an opera, murdered someone, then forgot what he was talking about halfway through.
the_roast:
Freddie Mercury walked into the studio and said 'What if we made a song that's three completely different songs having an identity crisis?' And honestly? Respect. We start with 'Is this the real life? Is this just fantasy?' which is the most philosophical opening since your buddy got too high at a party and won't stop asking deep questions. But before we can answer, our protagonist casually drops 'Mama, just killed a man' like he's confessing he forgot to buy milk. The emotional whiplash is real.

The middle section reads like someone's Google search history during a Renaissance Faire panic attack. 'Scaramouch' and 'Fandango' and 'Galileo' are just thrown in there like ingredients in a confused pasta recipe. And can we talk about how they yell 'Galileo' five times? We get it, you know ONE scientist's name. Then 'Bismillah' shows up for no reason except to make every karaoke singer sweat nervously. It's like the lyrical equivalent of opening every drawer in your house while cooking.

By the end, our murderer is somehow the victim, demanding 'So you think you can stone me and spit in my eye?' Sir, YOU killed someone. That was YOUR arc. Now you're mad about being held accountable? The audacity! Then we circle back to 'Nothing really matters' which is either profound nihilism or just gave up trying to make sense. It's the musical equivalent of 'anyway, here's Wonderwall' except it's 'anyway, nothing matters and also I committed homicide.'

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Assault by repetition and confusing the scientist with an opera
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Take a history class and learn there were other Renaissance figures

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Turning a trial into a theological opera without subtitles
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory subtitles for anyone who didn't take World Religions

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Beelzebub has a devil put aside for me
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Weirdest flex ever—bragging about having a reserved demon
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Think about your life choices that led to VIP seating in hell

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is an allegory about the five stages of grief, except there are like twelve stages and they're all happening at a Renaissance festival speed-dating event. The real meaning is that Freddie looked at song structure and said 'what if we just... didn't?'
final_verdict: A lyrical masterpiece of organized chaos that somehow works despite reading like three different homework assignments got shuffled together. It's beautifully bonkers, and we wouldn't have it any other way.
title: Bohemian Rhapsody
